key_points: A group from Texas A&M University at Galveston is working to save sea turtles affected by recent cold weather.
Last week's record low water temperatures along the Texas coast stunned thousands of sea turtles.
Christopher Marshall and his team have responded to more than 150 turtles, treating around 70.
The Gulf Center for Sea Turtle Research collaborates with the Sea Turtle Stranding and Salvage Network for rescue efforts.
Over 100 volunteers, including students and Texas Parks and Wildlife Department personnel, are involved.
Rescued turtles are kept in a 60-degree room for about 24 hours and examined by veterinarians before being released.
The Houston Zoo provides veterinary oversight for the sea turtle treatment process.
The aim is to quickly return healthy turtles to the Gulf of Mexico, where water temperatures are more suitable.
Green sea turtles are the main species being treated for cold stunning.
Despite efforts, the mortality rate for the cold-stunned turtles is around 50%.
spokespersons: Christopher Marshall (Professor in marine biology at Texas A&M-Galveston, Director of the Gulf Center for Sea Turtle Research)
